C.label: C
C.summary: Pressure: wound of failure; fear of being irrelevant.
C.long: Under stress, the nervous system makes a bargain: it tries to prevent being irrelevant. The wound is failure, so it becomes vigilant about tone, intent, and reciprocity. This is where the pattern can turn sharp: it makes rules out of pain, and it forgets repair. If unintegrated, it begins to punish what it actually longs for.

D.label: D
D.summary: Integration: virtue with warmth; boundaries with repair.
D.long: Integration looks like clean language and smaller drama. Refiner's Glossary of Measured Fire — The Hollow becomes real when it stops using control as a substitute for safety. It chooses tenderness without contempt, sets boundaries without spectacle, and repairs quickly when it misses. Its legacy is steadiness: a life that matches its own ethics.

name: Protector's Psalter of the Green Lamp — The Dawn (new vows)

psychology.notes: Integrated expression strengthens regulation: faith-in-action becomes a nervous-system anchor.

sociology.notes: It models repair instead of performance.

pedagogy.notes: Needs challenge + rest; mastery is paced.

anthropology.notes: Historically this shows up in undefined: the one entrusted with boundaries and meaning.

gifts: Turns humiliation into steadiness rather than spectacle.
Carries mercy like a lantern: visible, not blinding.
Uses creative grit to make rooms safer.
Oath: “I will not confuse control with care.”
risks: Becoming the “responsible one” instead of a whole person.
Carrying others’ fear like it’s a duty.
growth: Let rest be part of discipline.
relationships: Bonds through reliability; trust comes before intensity.
Paradox: it protects others by hiding from them.

A.label: A
A.long: You recognize Protector's Psalter of the Green Lamp — The Dawn (new vows) by what it refuses to do. It organizes identity around hope & renewal, with fresh paper-imagery threading through its choices. At its best, it practices mercy in public and private. The gift is creative grit, and it shows up as a habit—not a moment.
